items.question: "Alter" means other. In this sentence, His altruism is evident from his generosity. Altruism means _____.
"ego" means I. In this sentence, The egocentric believes that the world revolves around him. Egocentric means _____.
"Carn" means flesh. In the sentence, <u>Carnality</u> is the theme of many movies today. The underlined word means _____.

choices.text: indulgence in pleasure of the body

items.question: The vivacious manner of the starlet makes her popular.
Giving help to the flood victims was a magnanimous act.
Researchers, doctors, and scientists are working hard to discover a panacea and make this world a truly pleasant place to live in.
The bibulous man cannot eat without wine.
We cannot send a letter of thanks to an anonymous writer.
The dolorous attitude makes her look rather old for her age.
Her gregarious nature makes him have many friends wherever he goes.
The consummate performer received a standing ovation from the audience.
The student could not think of a way to placate their teacher.
A pregnant woman must be extra careful to prevent her child from contracting congenital diseases.
"A man who attempts to be his own doctor has a fool for his patient."

choices.text: A doctor who tries to cure himself is a fool
A person who goes to the doctor is a fool
The sick should try to cure themselves
A sick person should see a doctor

items.question: "A fool's tongue is long enough to cut his throat."

choices.text: The man has a very long tongue.
The fool has a sharp tongue.
One who cuts his throat is a fool.

items.question: "One man's meat is another man's poison."

choices.text: Those with a healthy digestive system cannot be poisoned.
People should make sure that the food they eat is not poisonous.
Good food may turn out to be poisonous.
Not everyone has the same tastes and habits as others.

items.question: "Criticism comes easier than craftsmanship."

choices.text: many people easily find fault with others.
It is easier to find fault than to work.
It takes time to create something.
We have many critics but few creators.

items.question: "The end justifies the means."

choices.text: A man should work hard to achieve his goal.
The speaker does not care what method he uses as long as he gets what he wants.
He who works hard will succeed.

items.question: "It is not a question of what a man knows, but what use he makes of what he knows." - J. G. Holland

choices.text: Get all the knowledge he can.
Make the best use of his time.

items.question: "I believe that every right implies a responsibility, every opportunity an obligation, every possession a duty." - J.D. Rockefeller

choices.text: A man has both rights and responsibilities.
All men must know their rights.
A man must accept his responsibilities.
It is important that a man know what he should do.

items.question: "We are form believers in the maxim that for all right judgement of any man or thing, it is useful, nay, essential to see his good qualities before pronouncing him bad." - Thomas Carlyle

choices.text: Judge a man by his actions.
When judging a man, look at his good points first.
Do not judge a man by his physical appearance.
Always look at a man you are judging.

items.question: "He who is the slowest in making a promise is the most faithful in the performance of it." - Jean Jacques Rousseau

choices.text: People who easily make promises quickly forget them.
A person who seldom promises is he who keeps his word.
Do not promise what you do not intend to keep.

items.question: "Bear in mind that children of all ages have one thing in common - they close their ears to advice and open their eyes to example." - The Tablet

choices.text: Children learn by what they see.
Advise children often so that they will become responsible.
Action and words are necessary for growth.

items.question:
[ "Grass" by Carl Sandburg ]
Pile the bodies high at Austerlitz and Waterloo.
Shovel them under and let me work -
I am the grass, I cover all.
And pile them high at Gettysburg.
And pile them high at Ypres and Verdun.
Shovel them under and let me work.
Two years, ten years, and the passengers ask the conductor:
     What place is this?
     Where are we now?
     I am the grass.
     Let me work.
What is common among the places mentioned in the poem?

choices.text: They used to be war zones.
They are all verdant or grassy.

items.question: What does Sandburg's "The Grass" clearly suggest?

choices.text: Deaths in war are often forgotten.
Without war, there can be no peace.
To die for one's country is a glorious act.

items.question: What does the poem reveal about the grass?

choices.text: It helps maintain peace and order.
It covers the graves of soldiers.
It can obscure memories of war.

items.question:
What sound device is exemplified in the first two lines of Poe's "The Raven"?
Deep into the darkness peering, long I stood there wondering, fearing,
Doubting, dreaming dreams no mortal ever dared to dream before;
But the silence was unbroken, and the stillness gave no token
What sound is being repeated above?
In Nathaniel Hawthorne's Minister's Black Veil, what does the Minister refer to as "an hour to come... when all of us shall cast aside our veils"?

Who is alluded alluded to as the Captain in the following lines from Whitman's poem?
O Captain! My Captain! Our fearful trip is done,
The ship has weather'd every rack, the prize we sought is won.

In the following dialogue, what Filipino value is affirmed by Mario's statement?
GLORIA: So, for a measly apply, you lost a job you needed so much-
MARIO: I wouldn't mind losing a thousand jobs for an apple for my daughter!

Food spoilage is an undesirable action of bacteria. It is counteracted by modern methods by canning, refrigeration, and freezing. If spoiled food is eaten, the result can be food poisoning. Food poisoning is not an infectious disease. It is not passed from one organism to another. However, in food poisoning, bacterial toxins have some effects on the host as they do in infectious diseases.
If spoiled food is eaten, the result can be _____.
Spoilage is counteracted by modern methods of _____.
Food spoilage is caused by _____.
Which of the following sentences is false?

choices.text: Food poisoning is not an infectious disease.
Food poisoning is passed from one organism to another.
Food poisoning is the result of eating spoiled food.
All the statements above are false.

items.question: The speaker delivered a well-prepared but long speech on the energy crisis. Soon the audience began yawning.

choices.text: The speaker is not good in pronunciation.
The audience appreciated the speaker's effort.

items.question: The girl looked at the man with one eyebrow slightly raised. Her face wore a scowl and her lips were puckered.

choices.text: She was in an ugly mood.

items.question: The lame boy sat by the window all day. He was overwhelmed by the endless sight of the fast-moving vehicles and people hurrying across the street and along the sidewalk.

choices.text: The boy was in a barrio.
The boy was in a field.
The scene was a remote town.
The boy was on a busy city street.

items.question: The woman opened the telegram. Her eyes widened in horror and disbelief, and then she cried in agony.

Education is a life-long process which requires studying and learning from previous experiences. It is not enough to be educated as it is to be cultured.
The paragraph best supports the idea that:

choices.text: Education means more than being a cultured person.
To be called a cultured person requires a continuing education.
A cultured person learns and profits from previous educational experiences.

items.question: "As he makes his bed, so he must lie on it." The quotation implies that

choices.text: One should face the consequences of his actions.
A person should prepare the be he'll lie on.

items.question: Rumor mongering is like letting a bagful of feathers on top of a tall building on a windy day. The quotation best supports the idea that:

choices.text: False loose talks are impossible to retrieve when already scattered around.
A feasible cure to gossip is not to talk.

items.question: "Early to bed, early to rise, keeps a man healthy, wealthy, and wise." means

choices.text: sleep early and wake up early so you will become wealthy
develop healthy habits of going to bed early
sleeping is the root of making wealth
sleeping will give you a healthy mind

items.question: What does it mean by saying, "Not all close eyes are asleep."?

choices.text: A person may seem to be unaware of something but actually the opposite is true.
When we sleep sometimes we open our eyes.
Sleeping is not always closing our eyes.

items.question: What is meant by live within your means?

choices.text: Liking is the means of growing.
Growing is the means to live.

items.question:
I Shall Not Pass This Way Again
Through this toilsome road alas!
Once and only once I pass;
If a kindness I may sow
I a good deed I may do
To a suffering fellowman
Let me do it while I can
No delay, for its plain
I shall not pass this way again
What is the mood of the first two lines?
What word in the poem means involving work?
What does road and way symbolize?
What does the poem imply?

choices.text: We are on earth to work.
We live but once on earth.

items.question: What virtue does the poem focus on?
What is the message of the poem?

choices.text: We have only one chance of helping others, so let us not delay doing good deeds.
Life is short, so let us enjoy every moment of it.
We can always delay our work because tomorrow is forever.
Helping others is a good deed.

items.question:
AFTER THE RAIN
The rain halts,
The wind ceases,
The girls
Again spread out their colorful clothes in the sun;
The children
Chase a rainbow on the lawn
Look!
Who has painted another coat of fresh color on the blue hill?
Listen!
The cornstalks are talking in their crackling voice.
~ Kai Yu Hsu
What happened to the hills?

choices.text: They turned to a fresh color.
The rainbow set on the lawn.

items.question: What does the last line mean?

choices.text: The blue hills are painted again.
The cornstalks promise a plentiful harvest.

items.question:
THE MORNING GLORY
The morning glory climbs above my head,
Pale flowers of white and purple, blue and red.
I  am disquieted.
Down in the withered grasses something stirred;
I thought it was his footfall that I heard.
Then a grasshopper chirped.
I climbed the hill just as the new moon showed,
I saw him coming on the southern road.
My heart lays down its load.
~ Confucius
How does the speaker of the poem feel at the sight of the morning glory?
What description of white and purple, blue and red flowers justified the speaker's feeling?
What disturbed the speakers thought and feeling?
The moon was visualized by the speaker as
What is the meaning of the last line?
Why did the speaker's feelings change?
Around what central theme does the poem revolve?

choices.text: the heavy heart of one sitting down
the dull moment when one is alone

items.question:
On that trip to the old village, Grandfather took me along. He also took my cousins Juanito, his namesake and favorite among his grandchildren, and Alejo, who, though somewhat doltish, was big for his age and strong as a horse. We made a curious crew.
Which of the following phrases best describes Alejo?
What figure of speech does the sentence, "Alejo is as strong as a horse." exemplify?

Sebio laughed. He was again his likeable self. He tried to catch the outstretched hand, but like lightning it was withdrawn, and when he stood up the girl was gone. He sat down again.
What are compared in the above paragraph?
Which of the following line is a simile?
Why was the hand compared to a lightning?

He saw the heat waves in the glare
As devils on the stage of fire,
Reproached the sky and saw the rain
As diablos dancing in the mire.
What are compared in the first two lines?
In the last two lines, devils are like

That night our friar kept vigil in the sacristy. Pacing the stone floor, he said his beads, clinging to them as to something familiar and benevolent, a part of the known world, and a weapon against the nameless, ageless, meaningless horror outside. He had witnessed again the little ceremony around the tree. Pausing at the window, he looked into the now silent patio. A slip of moon was abroad; the dense tree let fall its light in slivers. Upon pavement, the bowl shone luminous and mocking.
To what do the "beads" in the paragraph refer?
How does Nick Joaquin describe the light falling from the dense tree?
Which of the following phrases describes the "beads" the friar holds?

THE ORCHID
Under the rock
In a deep shady hollow
The graceful green orchid
Puts forth
Its pale leaves
Its glory is wasted
There's no eye
To see it,
And its fragrance
Is spilled
On the velvety moss.
The speaker of the poem would like to describe the flower through the phrase, "the graceful green orchid." What does it mean?
How does the speaker see the orchid?
What does the speaker emphasize in the line, "It's glory is wasted"?
What happens to the flower's fragrance?

choices.text: It is shared with other flowers.
It is stocked in the shady hollow.
It is spilled on the velvety moss.

items.question: What characteristic of the poet is revealed by the poem?
The speaker implies that something must be done to the green orchid, according to him what should it be?

choices.text: Display the flower so others may see its beauty.
Leave the flower under the rock.
Take care of the flower so that it can provide beauty.

items.question:
Why does the sea laugh Mother,
As it glints beneath the sun?
It is thinking of the joys, my child,
That it wishes everyone.
Why does the sea sob Mother,
As it breaks on the rocky shore?
It recalls the sorrows of the world
And weeps forevermore.
Why is the sea so peaceful Mother,
As if it were fast asleep?
It would give our tired hearts, dearest child,
The comforts of the deep.
What does the child ask in the poem?

choices.text: the cause of the high tide
the cause of what the sea does

items.question: What does the sea wish for everyone?
What does the sea do when it recalls the sorrows of the world?
According to the speaker in Natividad Marquez' poem, why does the sea sob?

choices.text: it breaks on the rocky shore
it recalls the sorrows of the world

items.question: Which of these phrases does not show a human quality?

The moon is a pale yellow-orange disc
on the edge of the sea.
There is a trail of light
on the shimmering waters
leading to the moon.
What are compared in the above passage?
To what does the "trail of light on shimmering waters" refer?

I was a kakawate tree. I grew on the bank of the river. I had been there for more years than I could remember. And my branches spread out, some of them reaching almost halfway across the river.
How is personification expressed in the paragraph?

choices.text: the kakawate tree has fresh leaves
the kakawate tree talks about itself

items.question: "I was a kakawate tree" is an example of?
